questions.question: What can you say about the IR and Raman activity of the normal modes CO<sub>2</sub>?

answers.a: They will be both IR and Raman active
answers.b: They will be both IR and Raman inactive
answers.c: Its IR active modes will be Raman inactive
answers.d: IR active modes will be Raman active but not vice versa

explanations.c: For molecules containing a center of symmetry, IR active modes are Raman inactive and vice versa.

questions.question: Which of the following modes of CO<sub>2</sub> will be Raman active?

explanations.c: CO<sub>2</sub> is known to follow the role of mutual exclusion, i.e. IR active modes are Raman inactive and vice versa. Only those modes which produces a change in dipole moment will be IR active. Symmetric stretch does not produce any change in the dipole moment and hence will be IR inactive and Raman active.

questions.question: Which of the following is true for CO2?

answers.a: Symmetric stretch has higher frequency than asymmetric stretch
answers.b: Symmetric stretch has lower frequency than asymmetric stretch
answers.c: Bending mode has higher frequency than asymmetric mode
answers.d: Bending mode has higher frequency than symmetric mode

explanations.b: The symmetric stretch is an easier deformation than the asymmetric stretch so the asymmetric stretch occurs at a higher wavenumber. The bending vibration is much easier than stretching so this occurs at a much lower wavenumber.
